Award.AwardTitle: IOS: Regulation of hematopoietic development by the peripheral nervous system
Award.AbstractNarration:
One of the outstanding questions in animal development is how sensory inputs, through local innervation by the peripheral nervous system (PNS), regulate organ microenvironments and stem cell niches. The proposed research addresses this question using a simple invertebrate model, i.e. the Hematopoietic Pockets (HPs) in the body wall of the optically transparent Drosophila melanogaster larva. In this system, blood cells develop in direct physical contact with segmentally repeated sensory PNS clusters, and functionally rely on the PNS for their attraction, proliferation and trophic survival. The objective of the proposed research is to identify (1) which responses of the hematopoietic cells are regulated by PNS activity, and (2) what are the cellular and molecular mechanisms in the relay of PNS activity to blood cell signaling, using a combination of inducible genetic systems, live imaging and ex vivo analyses. The long-term goal of this research is to understand the signals through which development of the hematopoietic system is modulated by the peripheral nervous system and its sensory inputs. This work is significant because it is expected to reveal general principles how the development of animal tissues is regulated by the PNS and its afferent inputs, allowing adaptation of the animal.
The proposed research will benefit global and local research communities and integrate the education of underprivileged students. Scientists on the project will contribute to the scientific community and the education of students and teachers through traditional approaches and by developing a Drosophila Genetics App for smartphones to map out genetic strategies that will be made publicly available.

POR.DRECONTENT:
One of the outstanding questions in biology is how sensory inputs, and the sensory nervous system, modulate organ development and homeostasis. The goal of this project was to understand how the sensory nervous system and its activity direct the development of the hematopoietic system. We addressed this question using a simple conserved genetic model organism, the fruitfly Drosophila melanogaster.

Investigating how blood cell development is affected by experimental sensory neuron activation and silencing, we found that both blood cell proliferation and transdifferentiation between two blood cell types depend on sensory neuron activity. We further identified molecular mechanisms of this regulation, revealing that both blood cell proliferation and transdifferentiation are regulated through Activin-β (Actβ), a TGF-β family ligand that is produced by sensory neurons, and the corresponding dSmad2 signaling pathway in blood cells. In a parallel approach, we confirmed that blood cell adaptation in the Drosophila model takes place at the larval stage, through the interface of sensory neurons and resident hemocyte clusters and other mechanisms, while in the adult fly no significant blood cell production is detectable, even under immune challenge of bacterial infection. This research identified a fundamental new role of sensory neuron activity in the development of organ systems, specifically the hematopoietic system. It provided proof of principle of molecular links between neuronal activity and animal development. Our findings suggest direct coupling of blood cell development with stimuli that activate sensory neurons. Future research is geared to identify specific sensory inputs that drive blood cell development and adaptation through this axis.

Regarding the broader impacts, this research provided training opportunities for multiple undergraduate students, graduate students, and postdocs. The PI and undergraduate students developed a prototype of a Drosophila genetics teaching app for the iPhone. The PI and members of the laboratory engaged in public science teaching events, With the goal to provide broader training to scientists of all levels, students and teachers, the PI and members of the lab authored teaching video articles on methods in molecular biology.
